Arnold and all,

It's "Nobuie Tsuba Shu," 1926, Nakamura Kakudayu & Akiyama Kyusaku.

Or the reprint with supplemental material from 1981, published by Token Shunju Shinbunsha, Tokyo.

Not all currently recognized Nobuie tsuba are illustrated, but they're great books.

Jim 



  He
  collected dozens and dozens of oshigata of Nobuiye, some very
  unassuming, as was the found one I refereed to, and they were published
  by a Mr. Nakayama, or Nakamura or something close to that (only my poor
  brain as a reference here).
